questionvariables.text: a:rand_with_step(2,8,1); b:rand_with_step(20,40,10); c:a*b; d:b/5; e:a*b/10; ta1:1/a; simp:false; f:5/e; g:d/10; wa1:(5+d)/(e+10);

You added the fractions by calculating numerator plus numerator and denominator plus denominator. But fractions cannot be added like that. Example: \(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{4}=\frac{3}{4}\). First, the fractions must be expanded so that the denominators are equal. Then the numerators are added. Example:

\(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{4}=\frac{1\cdot2}{2\cdot2}+\frac{1}{4}=\frac{2}{4}+\frac{1}{4}=\frac{3}{4}\)

name.text: t1-01-bi-b Simplifying two fractions with variables

questiontext.text:
Shorten and summarize as much as possible.

\(\frac{{@myvar1@}\cdot{@myvar2@}\cdot{@myvar3@}}{{@myvar4@}\cdot{@myvar5@}\cdot{@myvar6@}} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: \(\frac{a^3\,b ^2\,c}{a^5\,b\,c^3} = \frac{a\,a\,a\,b\,b\,c}{a\,a\,a\,a\,b\,c\,c\,c}\)

questionvariables.text: varlist:[a,b,c,x,y,z]; mya:rand(varlist); varlist:delete(mya,varlist); myb:rand(varlist); varlist:delete(myb,varlist); myc:rand(varlist); powers:makelist(rand(5)+1, 6); myvar1: mya^powers[1]; myvar2: myb^powers[2]; myvar3: myc^powers[3]; myvar4: mya^powers[4]; myvar5: myb^powers[5]; myvar6: myc^powers[6]; d:(myvar1*myvar2*myvar3)/(myvar4*myvar5*myvar6); ta1:d;

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can go even further simplify.

Example: \(\frac{a^3\,b^2\,c}{a^5\,b\,c^3} = \frac{a\mkern-5mu/\,a\mkern-5mu/\,a\mkern-5mu/\,b\,b\mkern-5mu/\,c\mkern-5mu/}{a\mkern- 5mu/\,a\mkern-5mu/\,a\mkern-5mu/\,a\,a\,b\mkern-5mu/\,c\mkern-5mu/\,c\,c} = \frac{b}{a^2\,c^2}\)

name.text: t1-01-bi-c Simplifying two fractions with variables and numbers

questiontext.text:
Shorten and summarize as much as possible.

\(\frac{{@nom1@}}{{@denom1@}} \cdot \frac{{@nom2@}}{{@denom2@}} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: First sort on a fraction bar. Example: \(\frac{49\,a}{7\,b} \cdot \frac{21\,a\,b}{7\,a\,c} = \frac{49\,a\cdot 21\,a\,b}{7\,b \cdot 7\,a\,c} = \frac{49 \cdot 21 \cdot a \cdot a \cdot b}{7 \cdot 7 \cdot a \cdot b \cdot c}\)

questionvariables.text: num1:rand_with_step(5,8,1); varlist:[a,b,c,u,v,w,x,y ,z]; myvars:[]; myvars:append(myvars,[rand(varlist)]); varlist:delete(myvars[1], varlist); myvars:append(myvars,[rand(varlist)]); varlist :delete(myvars[2],varlist); myvars:append(myvars,[rand(varlist)]); num2:rand_with_step(3,7,1); num3:rand_with_step(3,7,1); nom1:num1 *num2*myvars[1]; denom1:num1*myvars[2]; nom2:num1*num3*myvars[1]*myvars[2]; denom2:num1*myvars[1]*myvars[3]; ta1:(nom1/denom1)*(nom2/denom2); /*All variables in the Numerators with a variable in the denominator are shortened.*/wa1:((nom1/myvars[1])*(nom2/myvars[1]))/((denom1*denom2)/myvars[1]);

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: Du kannst noch weiter vereinfachen.

Du hast offensichtlich die Variable {@myvars[1]@} im Nenner gegen beide Variablen in den Zählern gekürzt. Bei der Multiplikation von Brüchen kannst du immer nur einen Faktor gegen den anderen kürzen. Beispiel: \(\frac{36}{6} = \frac{6\cdot6}{6} = \frac{6\mkern-5mu/\cdot6}{6\mkern-5mu/} = \frac{6}{1} = 6\) und nicht \(\frac{36}{6} = \frac{6\cdot6}{6} \ne \frac{6\mkern-5mu/\cdot6\mkern-5mu/}{6\mkern-5mu/} = 1\;\).

This is how you can sort and shorten products on a fraction bar: \(\frac{49\,a}{7\,b} \cdot \frac{21\,a\,b}{7\,a\,c} =\frac{49\,a\cdot 21\,a\,b}{7\,b \cdot 7\,a\,c} = \frac{49 \cdot 21 \cdot a \cdot b}{7 \cdot 7 \cdot a\cdot b\cdot c} =\frac{49^7\mkern-14mu\large/ \small \; \cdot 21^3\mkern-14mu\large/\small \; \cdot a\mkern-5mu/ \cdot a \cdot b\mkern-5mu/}{7\mkern-5.5mu/ \cdot7\mkern-5.5mu/ \cdot a\mkern-5mu/\cdot b\mkern-5mu/\cdot c} =\frac{21\,a}{c}\)

name.text: t1-01-bi-d Shortening two fractions with terms

questiontext.text:
Shorten and summarize as much as possible together.

\(\frac{{@term1@}}{{@myvar@}}\cdot\frac{{@myvar@}^2}{({@term1@})({@term2@}){@myvar@}}=\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: Do you still know the saying “Only stupid people reduce sums”?!

questionvariables.text: myvar:rand([x,y,z]); term_summand1:rand_with_prohib(-3,3,[0]); term_summand2:rand_with_prohib(-3,3,[0,term_summand1]); term1:myvar+term_summand1; term2:myvar+term_summand2; ta1:term1/myvar*(myvar^2/(term1*term2*myvar)); /*wa1 means: naive shortened fraction*/ wa1:(term1-myvar)/1*(myvar^2/(term1*term2*myvar));

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can simplify even further.

Obviously, in the first fraction you canceled the variable {@myvar@} in the denominator against the variable {@myvar@} in the numerator. But that doesn't work because the variable {@myvar@} in the numerator forms a sum with another term. Example: \(3 = \frac{6}{2} = \frac{4+2}{2} \ne \frac{4 + 2\mkern-5.5mu/}{2\mkern-5.5mu/} = \frac{4}{1} = 4\;\).
Only whole factors may be reduced. For example: \(\frac{\boldsymbol{(x-1)}\cdot 2}{x \cdot \boldsymbol{(x-1)}} = \frac{2}{x}\)

questiontext.text:
Add or subtract and sum up as much as possible.

\({@exercise@} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: When adding and subtracting, the denominators of the fractions must be the same. Can you still remember the lowest common multiple?

questionvariables.text: a:rand_with_step(1,4,1)*2+1; fac1:rand_with_step(1,4,1); fac2:rand_with_prohib(1,4,[fac1]); denoms:[a, a*fac1,a*fac2]; nums:makelist(rand_with_step(1,denoms[i]-1,2),i,3); signs:makelist(rand_with_prohib(-1,1,[0]),3); fractions:makelist(signs[i]*nums[i]/denoms[i],i,3); fractions:random_permutation(fractions); ta1:fractions[1]+fractions[2]+fractions[3]; simp:false; exercise:fractions[1]+fractions[2]+fractions[3]; /*wa1 means: naive addition*/ wa1:(num(fractions[1])+num(fractions[2])+num(fractions[3]))/(denom(fractions[1])+denom(fractions[2])+denom(fractions[3]));

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can simplify even further.

You added the fractions by calculating numerator plus numerator and denominator plus denominator. But fractions cannot be added like this. Example: \(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{4}=\frac{3}{4}\). First, the fractions must be expanded so that the denominators are the same. Then the numerators are added. Example:

\(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{4}=\frac{1\cdot2}{2\cdot2}+\frac{1}{4}=\frac{2}{4}+\frac{1}{4}=\frac{3}{4}\)

To make the denominators equal, you must expand them so that they have the same denominator. Then the numerators can be added. The lowest common multiple of For example, 5, 10 and 15 can be found by writing down the respective series and looking for the smallest common number.

name.text: t1-01-cb Addition of fractions with variables and the same denominator

questiontext.text:
Add or subtract and summarize as far as possible.

\({@exercise@} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: Think carefully about what a minus sign in front of a fraction means.

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can simplify even further.
You obviously have not entered the minus signs correctly resolved.

Tip: A minus in front of the fraction belongs to the whole fraction: applies to the whole numerator or denominator (often the numerator is used).

\(\Rightarrow -\frac{a-1}{a} = \frac{-\boldsymbol{(a-1)}}{a} = \frac{-a+1}{a}\)

Important for sums in the numerator!!!

name.text: t1-01-cc Addition of fractions with variables and different denominators

questiontext.text:
Add or subtract and summarize as far as possible.

\({@exercise@} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: Each partial denominator (here: {@myvars[1]@}, {@myvars[2]@}, {@myvars[3]@}) must be a factor in the common denominator occur.

questionvariables.text: varlist:[a,b,c,x,y,z]; myvars:[]; myvars:append(myvars,[rand(varlist)]); varlist:delete(myvars[1],varlist); myvars:append(myvars,[rand(varlist)]); varlist:delete(myvars[2],varlist); myvars:append(myvars,[rand(varlist)]); fractions:[(1+myvars[1])/myvars[1], rand_with_step(2,5,1)/myvars[2], myvars[1]/myvars[3]]; fractions:random_permutation(fractions); exercise:fractions[1]+fractions[2]+fractions[3]; common_denom:denom(fractions[1])*denom(fractions[2])*denom(fractions[3]); ta1:((num(fractions[1])*denom(fractions[2])*denom(fractions[3]))+(num(fractions[2])*denom(fractions[1])*denom(fractions[3]))+(num(fractions[3])*denom(fractions[1])*denom(fractions[2])))/common_denom; ta1alt:(expand((num(fractions[1])*denom(fractions[2])*denom(fractions[3])))+expand((num(fractions[2])*denom(fractions[1])*denom(fractions[3])))+expand((num(fractions[3])*denom(fractions[1])*denom(fractions[2]))))/common_denom;

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can go even further simplify.

To get a common denominator for fractions with variables in the denominator, all the partial denominators can be multiplied together.

Example: In the term \(\frac{1+a}{a}+\frac{2}{b}+\frac{a}{c}\) the common denominator is \(a \cdot b \cdot c\). This is how you need to expand so that the numerators can be added:

\(\frac{(1+a) \boldsymbol{\cdot b \cdot c} }{a \boldsymbol{\cdot b \cdot c}}+\frac{2 \boldsymbol{\cdot a \cdot c}}{\boldsymbol{a} \cdot b \boldsymbol{\cdot c}}+\frac{a \boldsymbol{\cdot a \cdot b}}{\boldsymbol{a \cdot b} \cdot c}\)

Remember: When expanding, you only multiply. The expression \(1+a\) is a sum. \(\Rightarrow\) Use brackets when expanding!

name.text: t1-01-cd Addition of fractions with one variable and different denominators

questiontext.text:
Add or subtract and summarize as much as possible.

\({@exercise@} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

questionvariables.text: myvar:rand([x,y,z]); nums:makelist(rand_with_step(2,5,1),2); fractions:[(nums[1]+myvar)/myvar^2,(nums[2]-myvar^2)/myvar]; common_denom:myvar^2; ta1:(num(fractions[1])-num(fractions[2])*myvar)/common_denom; ta1alt:(num(fractions[1])-expand(num(fractions[2])*myvar))/common_denom; exercise:fractions[1]-fractions[2]; /*wa1 means: didn't consider minus sign before bracket*/ wa1:(num(fractions[1])+(-nums[2]-myvar^2)*myvar)/common_denom;

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can go even further simplify.
You obviously did not resolve the minus signs correctly (see tip below).

To always get a common denominator for fractions with variables in the denominator, all partial denominators can be multiplied together.

Example: In the term \(\frac{3+x}{x^2}-\frac{5- x}{x}\) is a common denominator \(x^2 \cdot x = x^3\). If you look more closely at the partial denominators \(x^2\) and \(x\), you will notice that \(x\) already appears as a factor in \(x^2\). Because \(x^2 = x \cdot x\). Therefore, \(x^2\) can be chosen as the main denominator here.

To do this, it must be expanded as follows:

\(\frac{(3+x)}{x^ {2}}-\frac{(5-x^2) \boldsymbol{ \cdot x}}{x \boldsymbol{\cdot x}} = \frac{3+x}{x^{2}}-\frac{5x-x^3}{x^{\boldsymbol{2}}} = \frac{3+x-(5x-x^3)}{x^2} = \dots\)

Remember: When expanding, only multiplication takes place. The expression \(5-x^2\) is a sum. \(\Rightarrow\) brackets around it when expanding!

name.text: t1-01-ce Addition of fractions with variables and different denominators I (Update1)

questiontext.text:
Add or subtract and summarize as far as possible.

\({@exercise@} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: First treat numbers and variables separately to find the common denominator.

questionvariables.text: varlist:[a,b,c,x,y,z]; myvars:[]; myvars:append(myvars,[rand(varlist)]); varlist:delete(myvars[1],varlist); myvars:append(myvars,[rand(varlist)]); varlist:delete(myvars [2],varlist); myvars:append(myvars,[rand(varlist)]); numbers:makelist(rand_with_step(2,5,1), 5); factors:random_permutation([1,2,4]); /*only +*/ signs:makelist(rand_with_prohib(1,1,[0]),2); fractions:[(numbers[1]*myvars[1]-numbers[2]*myvars[2])/(factors[1]*5*myvars[1]*myvars[2]), (numbers[3]* myvars[3]-numbers[4]*myvars[1])/(factors[2]*5*myvars[1]*myvars[3]), (myvars[3]^2-numbers[5])/( factors[3]*5*myvars[2]*myvars[3])]; tanum:(num(fractions[1])*(4/factors[1])*myvars[3]+num(fractions[2] )*(4/factors[2])*myvars[2]+num(fractions[3])*(4/factors[3])*myvars[1]); tanumalt:expand(tanum); tadenom:(5*4*myvars[1]*myvars[2]*myvars[3]); ta1:tanum/tadenom; /*fractions_to_show:random_permutation(fractions);*/ fractions_to_show:fractions; ta1alt:tanumalt/tadenom; fractions_to_show[2]:fractions_to_show[2]*signs[1]; fractions_to_show[3]:fractions_to_show[3]*signs[2]; exercise:fractions_to_show[1]+fractions_to_show[2]+fractions_to_show[3];

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can go even further simplify.

Tip: To form a common denominator, numbers and variables can be processed separately.

Example: In the term \(\frac{5\,z-4\,x}{10\,x\,z}+\frac{7\,y-3\,z}{20\,y\,z}+\frac{y^2-2}{5\,x\,y}\) \(20\) the least common multiple (LCM) of \(10\), \(20\) and \(5\) and \(x \cdot y \cdot z\) is the LCM of \(x \cdot z\), \(y \cdot z\) and \(x \cdot y\). The common denominator is therefore \(20 \cdot x \cdot y \cdot z\;\).

The fractions must now be expanded so that each denominator is \(20 \cdot x \cdot y \cdot z\;\). \(\frac{5\,z-4\,x}{10\,x\,z}\) is expanded by \(2 \cdot y\), \(\frac{7\,y-3\,z}{20\,y\,z}\) is expanded by \(x\), and \(\frac{y^2-2}{5\,x\,y}\) is expanded by \(4 \cdot z\). This gives:

\(\frac{(5\,z-4\,x)\boldsymbol{ \cdot 2\,y}}{10\,x\,z \boldsymbol{ \cdot 2\,y}}+\frac{(7\,y-3\,z) \boldsymbol{ \cdot x}}{20\,y\,z \boldsymbol{ \cdot x}}+\frac{(y^2-2) \boldsymbol{ \cdot 4\,z}}{5\,x\,y \boldsymbol{ \cdot 4\,z}}\)

\(= \frac{10\,y\,z-8\,x\,y}{20\,x\,y\,z}+\frac{7\,x\,y-3\,x\,z}{20\,x\,y\,z}+\frac{4\,y^2\,z-8\,z}{20\,x\,y\,z} = \dots\)

name.text: t1-01-cf Addition of fractions with variables and different denominators II

questiontext.text:
Add or subtract and summarize as far as possible.

\({@exercise@} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: 1) Think carefully about what a minus sign in front of a fraction means. 2) Each partial denominator (here: {@denom(main_fraction)@}, {@denom(fractions[1])@}, {@denom(fractions[2])@}) must appear as a factor in the common denominator. 3) First treat numbers and variables separately in order to find a common denominator.

questionvariables.text: varlist:[a,b,c,x,y,z]; myvars:[]; myvars:append(myvars,[rand(varlist)]); varlist:delete(myvars[1],varlist); myvars:append(myvars,[rand(varlist)]); numbers:rand_selection(makelist(i,i,5),2); denom_nums_origin:rand_selection([18,12,6],1)[1]; denom_nums:[denom_nums_origin, denom_nums_origin/2, denom_nums_origin/3]; main_fraction:(numbers[1]-myvars[1])/(denom_nums[1]*myvars[1]^2); fractions:[(myvars[2])/(denom_nums[2]*myvars[1]), (myvars[2]+numbers[2])/(denom_nums[3]*myvars[1]*myvars[2])]; tanum:num(main_fraction)*myvars[2]-num(fractions[1])*2*myvars[1]*myvars[2]-num(fractions[2])*3*myvars[1]; tanumalt:expand(tanum); tadenom:denom_nums_origin*myvars[1]^2*myvars[2]; ta1:tanum/tadenom; ta1alt:tanumalt/tadenom; fractions:random_permutation(fractions); simp:false; exercise:main_fraction-fractions[1]-fractions[2];

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can go even further simplify.

Tip: To form a common denominator, numbers and variables can be processed separately.

Example: In the term \(\frac{1-x}{18\,x^2}-\frac{y}{9\,x}-\frac{x+3}{6\,x\,y}\), \(18\) is the least common multiple (LCM) of \(18\), \(9\) and \(6\) and \(x^2 \cdot y\) is the GCD of \(x^2\), \(x\) and \(x \cdot y\). The common denominator is therefore \(18 \cdot x^2 \cdot y\;\).

The fractions must now be expanded so that the denominator in each is \(18 \cdot x^2 \cdot y\;\). \(\frac{1-x}{18\,x^2}\) is expanded by \(y\), \(\frac{y}{9\,x}\) is expanded by \(2\,x\,y\) and \(\frac{x+3}{6\,x\,y}\) is expanded by \(3 \cdot x\). This gives:

\(\frac{(1-x) \boldsymbol{\cdot y}}{18\,x^2 \boldsymbol{\cdot y}}-\frac{y \boldsymbol{\cdot 2\,x\,y}}{9\,x \boldsymbol{\cdot 2\,x\,y}}-\frac{(x+3) \boldsymbol{\cdot 3\,x}}{6\,x\,y \boldsymbol{\cdot 3\,x}}\)

\(= \frac{y-x\,y}{18\,x^2\,y}-\frac{2\,x\,y^2}{18\,x^2\,y}-\frac{3\,x^2+9\,x}{18\,x^2\,y} = \dots\)

\({@fractions[1]@}\cdot{@fractions[2]@} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: When multiplying, always calculate numerator times numerator and denominator times denominator.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can simplify even further.

The fractions should be multiplied. You added the fractions by calculating numerator plus numerator and denominator plus denominator. Aside from the fact that fractions cannot be added this way, the fractions should be multiplied.
You added the fractions beautifully, but the fractions should be multiplied

Two fractions can be multiplied by calculating numerator times numerator and denominator times denominator. Example: \(\frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{6}{5} = \frac{2 \cdot 6}{3 \cdot 5} = \frac{12}{15} = \frac{4}{5}\)

name.text: t1-01-db Multiplication of two fractions with variables

questiontext.text:
Multiply or divide and sum as far as possible.

\({@fractions[1]@} \cdot \frac{{@mya@}^2}{{@mya@}\cdot{@myb@}} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: When multiplying, always calculate numerator times numerator and denominator times denominator.

questionvariables.text: varlist:[a,b,c,x,y,z]; mya:rand(varlist); varlist:delete(mya,varlist); myb:rand(varlist); fractions:[mya/myb, mya^2/(mya*myb)]; fractions:random_permutation(fractions); ta1:fractions[1]*fractions[2]; simp:false; exercise:fractions[1]*fractions[2]; /*wa1 means: naively summed fractions with previously shortened the larger fraction*/ wa1:(2*mya)/(2*myb); /*wa2 means: naively summed fractions without previously shortening the larger fraction*/ wa2:(mya+myb^2)/(mya+myb*mya); /*wa3 means: correctly summed fractions instead of multiplied*/ wa3:fractions[1]+fractions[2]; /*wa1:num((fractions[1])+num(fractions[2]))/(denom(fractions[2])+denom(fractions[2])); /*wa2 means: summed fractions instead of multiplied wa2:fractions[1]+fractions[2];*/

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can simplify even further.

The fractions should be multiplied. You added the fractions by calculating numerator plus numerator and denominator plus denominator. Aside from the fact that fractions cannot be added this way, the fractions should be multiplied.

The fractions should be multiplied. You added the fractions by calculating numerator plus numerator and denominator plus denominator. Aside from the fact that fractions cannot be added this way, the fractions should be multiplied. You also did not simplify the fraction \({@mya@}^2/({@mya@}*{@myb@})\) sufficiently. It can be shortened to \({@mya@}/{@myb@}\).
You've added the fractions beautifully, but the fractions should be multiplied.

Two fractions can be multiplied by calculating numerator times numerator and denominator times denominator. Example: \(\frac{a}{b} \cdot \frac{a^2}{a\,b} = \frac{a}{b} \cdot \frac{a \cdot a}{a\,b} = \frac{a \cdot a \cdot a}{a \cdot b \cdot b} = \frac{a^3}{a\,b^2}\)

name.text: t1-01-dc Multiplication of fractions with numbers, fractions with variables, integers

questiontext.text:
Multiply or divide and summarize as far as possible together.

\({@factors[1]@}\cdot{@factors[2]@}\cdot{@factors[3]@} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: How can you write an integer as a fraction?

questionvariables.text: nums:rand_selection(makelist(i+1,i,8),3); nums:sort(nums); varlist:[a,b,c,x,y,z]; mya:rand(varlist); varlist:delete(mya,varlist); myb:rand(varlist); varlist:delete(myb,varlist); myc:rand(varlist); factors:[nums[1], (mya*myb)/myc, nums[2]/nums[3]]; factors:random_permutation(factors); ta1:factors[1]*factors[2]*factors[3]; simp:false; exercise:factors[1]*factors[2]*factors[3];

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can simplify even further.

Tip: Every integer can be written as a fraction by dividing it by 1. Example: \(3 \cdot \frac{a\,b}{c} \cdot \frac{5}{6} = \frac{3}{1} \cdot \frac{a\,b}{c} \cdot \frac{5}{6}\)

\( = \frac{3 \cdot a \cdot b \cdot 5}{1 \cdot c \cdot 6} = \frac{15\,a\,b}{6\,c} = \frac{5\,a\,b}{2\,c}\)

Note: In general, \(\cdot 1\) and \(: 1\) are always okay.

name.text: t1-01-dd Multiplication of two fractions with terms

questionvariables.text: varlist:[a,b,c,x,y,z]; myvars:rand_selection(varlist, 2); nums:rand_selection(makelist(i+1,i,9), 6); fractions:[(nums[1]*myvars[1]+nums[2]*myvars[2])/(nums[3]*myvars[2]+nums[4]*myvars[1]), (-nums[5]*myvars[1])/(nums[6]+myvars[1])]; ta1:fractions[1]*fractions[2]; taalt:combine(expand(ta1)); /*wa1 means: the multiplication of the numerator was done with only one summand of the first fraction’s numerator (the second one)*/ wa1:(nums[1]*myvars[1]+nums[2]*myvars[2]*num(fractions[2]))/(denom(fractions[1])*denom(fractions[2])); /*old_wa2: (nums[1]*myvars[1]*num(fractions[2])+nums[2]*myvars[2])/(denom(fractions[1])*denom(fractions[2]));*/ /*wa2 means the same as wa1 but with the denominators, so no brackets: first summand of second fraction is multiplied with last summand of first fraction*/ wa2:(num(fractions[1])*num(fractions[2]))/(nums[3]*myvars[2]+nums[4]*myvars[1]*nums[6]+myvars[1]); /*wa3 is the combination of wa1 and wa2*/ wa3:(nums[1]*myvars[1]+nums[2]*myvars[2]*num(fractions[2]))/(nums[3]*myvars[2]+nums[4]*myvars[1]*nums[6]+myvars[1]);

This means when multiplying the numerators you have to put brackets around the sum and multiply each summand of the first numerator by the factor of the other numerator.

You have multiplied the numerators correctly, but you have not taken into account that sums are multiplied as a whole in the denominator. This means when multiplying the denominators you have to put brackets around the sums and multiply each summand of one denominator by each summand of the other denominator.

You have not multiplied the sums as a whole. This concerns a sum in the numerator and the sums in the denominator. You have to put brackets in each case so that each summand is multiplied by every other summand.

When fractions are multiplied, the sums are multiplied as a whole.

Example: \(\frac{4\,x+10\,y}{5\,y+2\,x} \cdot \frac{-4\,x}{3+x} = \)\(\frac{\boldsymbol{(4\,x+10\,y)} \cdot -4\,x}{\boldsymbol{(5\,y+2\,x)} \cdot \boldsymbol{(3+x)}} = \dots\)

When two fractions are divided, the first fraction (dividend) is multiplied by the reciprocal of the second fraction (divisor).

Example: \(\large\frac{\frac{1}{3}}{\frac{3}{5}} = \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{5}{3} = \frac{5}{9}\)

questionvariables.text: power:rand_with_step(2,4,1); myvars:rand_selection([a,b,c,x,y,z],2); dividend:myvars[1]/myvars[2]; num:rand_with_step(1,5,1); divisor:(num-myvars[1])/(myvars[2]^power); ta1: dividend/divisor; /*wa1 means: multiplied fractions instead of division*/ wa1:dividend*divisor; /*wa2 means: multiplicative inversed the dividend instead of the divisor*/ wa2:dividend^(-1)*divisor; /*wa3 means: didn’t consider to multiply the denominator of the first fraction with the sum of the second fraction’s numerator as a whole*/ wa3:(num(dividend)*denom(divisor))/(myvars[2]*num-myvars[1]);

You have formed the correct reciprocal to then multiply the fractions, but you have not taken note of the brackets when multiplying.

When fractions are multiplied, the sums are multiplied as a whole.

Example: \(\frac{x}{a} : \frac{1-x}{a^2} = \frac{x}{a} \cdot \frac{a^2}{1-x}\)\(= \frac{x \cdot a^2}{a \cdot \boldsymbol{(1-x)}} = \dots\)

Tip: \(\boldsymbol{:}\) is the same as a double fraction bar.

Example: \(\large\frac{\frac{1}{3}}{\frac{3}{5}} = \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{5}{3} = \frac{5}{9}\)

questionvariables.text: nums:rand_selection(makelist(i+1,i,8), 3); nums:sort(nums); myvars:rand_selection([a,b,c,x,y,z],2); terms:[nums[1]*((1-myvars[1])/myvars[2]), (nums[2]/nums[3])*(myvars[2]^2/myvars[1])]; /*terms:random_permutation(terms);*/ ta1:terms[1]/terms[2]; taalt:combine(expand(ta1)); /*wa1 means: didn't consider to multiple first factor in the numerator with both summands of the fraction's numerator*/ wa1:((nums[1]*1-myvars[1])/myvars[2])/terms[2]; wa2:terms[1]*terms[2]; wa3:terms[1]^(-1)*terms[2];

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can go even further simplify.

When multiplying the factor {@nums[1]@} and the fraction \(\frac{1-{@myvars[1]@}}{{@myvars[2]@}}\) in the numerator of the double fraction, you must remember that sums are multiplied as a whole.

Example: \(5 \cdot \frac{1-a}{b} = \frac{5 \cdot \boldsymbol{(1-a)}}{b} = \dots\)
You have multiplied the fractions instead of dividing them.
You have taken the reciprocal of the first fraction (dividend), but you have to take the reciprocal of the second fraction (divisor) and then multiply the fractions to achieve a division. received.

Solution for an example task:

\(\large\frac{5 \cdot \frac{1-a}{b}}{\frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{b^2}{a}}\)\(\large = \frac{\frac{5 \cdot \boldsymbol{(1-a)}}{b}}{\frac{b^2}{3\,a}} = \frac{5 - 5\,a}{b} \cdot \frac{3\,a}{b^2}\)

\(\large = \frac{3\,a \cdot \boldsymbol{(5-5\,a)}}{b \cdot b^2} = \frac{15\,a - 15\,a^2}{b^3}\)

questiontext.text:
Calculate and summarize as far as possible.

\(\large\frac{\frac{{@nums_real_frac[1]@}}{{@nums_real_frac[4]@}}}{\frac{{@nums_real_frac[2]@}}{{@nums_real_frac[3]@}}}+{@int@} \cdot \frac{{@nums_unreal_frac[6]@}}{{@nums_unreal_frac[1]@}}-\frac{\frac{{@nums_unreal_frac[5]@}}{{@nums_unreal_frac[2]@}}}{\frac{{@nums_unreal_frac[4]@}}{{@nums_unreal_frac[3]@}}} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: Attention: Double fractions and summands => Point-before-line calculation

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can simplify even further.

You obviously did not follow the order of precedence.

Example: \(\large \frac{\frac{5}{6}}{\frac{1}{3}}+2 \cdot \frac{9}{6} = \frac{\frac{5}{6}}{\frac{1}{3}}+(2 \cdot \frac{9}{6}) \ne (\frac{\frac{5}{6}}{\frac{1}{3}}+2) \cdot \frac{9}{6}\)

Tip: Look at each summand individually and calculate: Double fractions resolve and summarize.

Example: \(\large \frac{\frac{5}{6}}{\frac{1}{3}}+2 \cdot \frac{9}{6}-\frac{\frac{13}{4}}{\frac{6}{5}} = \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{3}{1}+\frac{2}{1} \cdot \frac{9}{6}-\frac{13}{5} \cdot \frac{5}{6}\)

\(= (\frac{5}{6\mkern-5mu/^2} \cdot \frac{3\mkern-5mu/^1}{1})+(\frac{2\mkern-5mu/^1}{1} \cdot \frac{9}{6\mkern-5mu/^2})-(\frac{13}{5\mkern-5mu/^1} \cdot \frac{5\mkern-5mu/^1}{6})\)

\(= \frac{5}{2} + \frac{9}{2} - \frac{13}{6} = \frac{5 \cdot 3}{2 \cdot 3} + \frac{9 \cdot 3}{2 \cdot 3} - \frac{13}{6} = \frac{15}{6} + \frac{27}{6} - \frac{13}{6}\)

\(= \frac{15+27+13}{6} = \frac{55}{6}\)<\p>

questiontext.text:
Calculate and summarize as far as possible.

\({@factors[1]@}\cdot(\frac{{@nums[1]@}}{{@nums[6]@}}+\frac{{@nums[2]@}}{{@nums[5]@}})\cdot (1-\frac{{@nums[3]@}}{{@nums[4]@}})=\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: Multiply out carefully

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can simplify even further.

Here you have two options: Multiply everything out carefully or calculate the brackets before multiplying (recommended!)

Example: \(6 \cdot \cdot (\frac{3}{4}+\frac{1}{8}) \cdot (1-\frac{1}{4}) = 6 \cdot (\frac{3 \cdot 2}{4 \cdot 2}+\frac{1}{8}) \cdot (\frac{1 \cdot 4}{1 \cdot 4}-\frac{1}{4})\)

\(= 6 \cdot (\frac{6}{8}+\frac{1}{8}) \cdot (\frac{4}{4}-\frac{1}{4}) = 6 \cdot (\frac{7}{8}) \cdot (\frac{3}{4})\)

\( = \frac{6}{1} \cdot \frac{7}{8} \cdot \frac{3}{4} = \frac{6\mkern-5mu/^3 \cdot 7 \cdot 3}{1 \cdot 8\mkern-5mu/^4 \cdot 4} = \frac{63}{16}\)

questiontext.text:
Calculate and summarize as far as possible together.

\({@int@}\frac{{@nums[1]@}}{{@nums[4]@}}\cdot\frac{{@myvar@}}{{@nums[5]@}}+1-\frac{{@nums[6]@}-{@myvar@}}{\frac{{@nums[4]@}}{{@nums[3]@}}} =\)[[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

Tip: Attention: Double fraction and mixed fraction vs. improper Fraction

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can simplify even further.

You have obviously interpreted the mixed fraction \({@int@}\frac{{@nums[1]@}}{{@nums[4]@}}\) as multiplication \({@int@} \cdot \frac{{@nums[1]@}}{{@nums[4]@}}\). However, the mixed fraction here means \({@int@}\) whole and \(\frac{{@nums[1]@}}{{@nums[4]@}}\) part. Recommendation: Rewrite mixed fractions as improper fractions. Example:\(2\frac{1}{6} = 2+\frac{1}{6} = \frac{2 \cdot 6}{1 \cdot 6} + \frac{1}{6} = \frac{12}{6}+\frac{1}{6} = \frac{13}{6}\)

Tip: \(\frac{{@nums[6]@}-{@myvar@}}{\frac{{@nums[4]@}}{{@nums[3]@}}}\) is also a double fraction.

Make sure to put the brackets correctly.

Example: \(\frac{2-a}{\frac{7}{8}} = \boldsymbol{(}2-a\boldsymbol{)} \cdot \frac{8}{7}\)

Note: 1) Rewrite whole numbers as fractions. 2) Rewrite double fractions (example above). 3) Rewrite mixed fractions (example \(2\frac{1}{6}\) is \(\frac{13}{6}\;\)). 4) Dot-before-dash rule.

name.text: t3-01-k Fraction calculation rules Ig2 - Expanding a fraction with a binomial term 2 (copy)

questiontext.text:
Simplify and factorize the following expression using the binomial formulas.

{@task@}\(\,=\,\) [[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]


This is the final boss of the math world Fractional arithmetic rules and binomial formulas. If you can do this task, you have already mastered this world. First, use the binomial formulas to simplify the denominators. To then add the fractions, you must expand with a term.

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: You can simplify even further.
Apply the first binomial formula to factor the numerator.
Apply the second binomial formula to factor the denominator.
Apply the first binomial formula to factor the numerator and apply the second binomial formula to factor the denominator.

You obviously have the second term is multiplied (squared) by itself so that the denominators are equal. However, a fraction is not expanded in this way. The squared fraction is no longer equivalent to the previous fraction. Example: \((\frac{2}{5})^2 = \frac{4}{25} \ne \frac{2}{5}\;\) whereas \(\frac{2}{5} = \frac{2 \cdot 5}{5 \cdot 5} = \frac{10}{25}\;\). Please think again about what the second summand needs to be expanded with so that the denominators are equal.

You have obviously added the two fractions by calculating numerator plus numerator (above) and denominator plus denominator (below). Fractions cannot be added like this. Example: \( \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{4} \ne \frac{1+1}{2+4}\;\) . Fractions must be expanded so that they have the same denominator. Then the counters can be added: \(\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{4} = \frac{2}{4} + \frac{1}{4} = \frac{3}{4}\).

category.text: $course$/top/Question Pool Digital Mentoring/test_en/t5_rul Power calculation rules

name.text: t5-01-e Power calculation rules Ie - Apply power calculation rules

questiontext.text:
Use the power calculation rules to simplify the following expression.

{@RUL_a[3]@}\(\,=\,\)[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]


Here are the most important rules for calculating powers as a reminder. For \(x, y \neq 0\) and \(n, m \in \mathbb{Z}\) the following applies:
  • \(x^{n+m} = x^n\,x^m\;\)
    Example: \(2^5 = 2^{2+3} = 2^2 \cdot 2^3 = 4 \cdot 8 = 32\)
  • \(\left( x^n \right)^m = x^{n\,m}\;\)
    Example: \(\left( 2^2 \right)^3 = 2^6 = 64\)
  • \((x\,y)^n = x^n\,y^n\;\)
    Example: \(6^2 = (2 \cdot 3)^2 = 2^2 \cdot 3^2 = 4 \cdot 9 = 36\)
  • \(\frac{1}{x^n} = x^{-n}\)
    Example: \( \frac{1}{x^2} \cdot x^2 = x^{-2} \cdot x^2 = x^{-2+2} = x^0 = 1\)
  • \(\sqrt[n]{x} = x^{\frac{1}{n}}\)
    Example: \( \sqrt[3]{x} \cdot x^3 = x^{\frac{1}{3}} \cdot x^3 = x^{\frac{1}{3}+3} = x^1 = x\)

    To solve this task, you can combine several of the rules just explained.

prtcorrect.text: Correct. Well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Parttially correct.

truefeedback.text: Correct, but you can simplify even further.

Tip: When do you need the chain rule?

The chain rule is:

\(f(x) = u(v(x))\)

\(f'(x) = u'(v) \cdot v'\)

Example

\(f(x) = \sqrt{x^3+1} = (x^3+1)^{\frac{1}{2}}\)

\(f'(x) = \frac{1}{2} \cdot (x^3+1)^{-\frac{1}{2}} \cdot 3\,x^2\)

\(= \frac{3\,x^2}{2 \cdot (x^3+1)^{\frac{1}{2}}} = \frac{3\,x^2}{2\,\sqrt{x^3+1}}\)
